item.content:
The Planning:

I started a new project. Unnamed yet, but I already know about what will be. It looks a bit silly but I want to do a money manager. An application that you can add entries for expenses and incomes.

How I started? Planning! I am planning the database. I intend to use PostgreSQL for my database.

I am using dbdiagram.io to create my schemas

dbdiagram.io

On the left side I wrote in code what I want to represent in my tables. The rest of the screen is a graphical representation of the tables.

Very much references:

Ever you see “_id” on column is a reference to another table. The name that comes before is the name of the other table.

The representation in code is:

Ref: accounts.user_id > users.id

Table.Foreign Key > Other Table.Primary Key

Technologies:

I want to use in this project:

  • Elixir for backend
  • GraphQl for API
  • PostgreSQL for database
  • ReactJS for frontend
  • […] for Mobile

Go Up!

This is the first post of a saga. I want to documentation all status of project here and explain details about each process executed. When the project reaches maturity will be available in GitHub for viewing and contribution. Let’s work and do something different happen.

See you!


The link to Part 2 will be updated when available

item.content:
When I bought a Keychron K2 I knew it would work in Windows and Mac, but I use Linux. But itâ€™s just a keyboardâ€¦ it should work.

Well… It works! But on my OS Arch Linux with Gnome had a little problem. The FN keys didnâ€™t work perfectly. Actually the FN keys were for MacOS, not Windows.

How I fixed:

  • Use the switch on side of keyboard to change to Windows mode
  • Hold Fn + X + L for 4 seconds to set the key row to Function mode

Type in the terminal:

echo 0 | sudo tee /sys/module/hid_apple/parameters/fnmode

When doing this your keyboard should work perfectly.

With a small detail: to persist this change you need to add a module option for hid_apple

echo "options hid_apple fnmode=0" | sudo tee -a /etc/modprobe.d/hid_apple.conf

Important!

Now you need to rebuild your initramfs if hid_apple module is included.

  • Ubuntu: sudo update-initramfs -u
  • Arch: mkinitcpio -P

Good! After reboot your OS don’t will go miss this configuration and your FN keys will work as if it were Windows.


Source: Mike Shade
